This is a brief introduction to the concepts in functional analysis, which are used in the variational formulation in finite element methods to solve the PDE. The content below is from the page 11-12 and page 27-31 in the book Computational Methods for Quantitative Finance: Finite Element Methods for Derivative Pricing1.

Function Spaces

Definition of partial derivatives

The variational formulation in the finite element method requires tools from functional analysis, in particular Hilbert spaces. Let $G$ be a non-empty open subset of $\mathbb{R}^d$. If a function $u: G \to \mathbb{R}$ is sufficiently smooth, we denote the partial derivatives of $u$ by $$ D^{\mathbf{n}} u(x):=\frac{\partial^{|\mathbf{n}|} u(x)}{\partial x _1^{n _1} \cdots \partial x _d^{n _d}}=\partial _{x _1}^{n _1} \cdots \partial _{x _d}^{n _d} u(x), \quad x=\left(x _1, \ldots, x _d\right) \in G, $$ where $\mathbf{n}=\left(n _1, \ldots, n _d\right) \in \mathbb{N} _0^d$ is a multi-index. The order of the partial derivative is given by $|\mathbf{n}|=\sum _{i=1}^d n _i$.
